course.subject: ENGG
course.name: Information Technology Revolution: Past, Present and Future
course.description: This course introduces the basic concepts in information technology and explores the many applications of information technology in our daily life from consumer electronics to internet to various sectors including medicine, business, and social networking, etc. Key technology breakthroughs throughout the development of information technology and its impact to various aspect of our society will be studied. These include the invention of the 1st transistor, concept of computing machine, representation of information in digital formats, miniaturization via VLSI technology, electronic communications from emails, mobile phones, sms, to video skype, imaging technologies in medical field, internet and social networking, image and video technology and websites like youtube, etc. The focus is to identify the key technological advances in information technology and understand how these advances led to revolutionary changes in our life and society.

reviews.author: Park
reviews.title: Welcome to the abyss! 쏠찕힑 맑핡게요 한쿩인들 이거 핡찌 마쎄요
reviews.comment_content:
If you sucessfully manged to get into this course unboubtly realizing the competition of the cours'e quota was not that rough, then congratulation! You just stepped into the hell with your own foot!

ENGG1150 covers all lame and boring computer related contents that may fry your brain. Nevertheless, if you do manage to overcome it all, you will be awarded with sweet gradings.

This course is a dungeon of computer engineering. The basic contents covers the history and evolution of computer engineering and software developments.

You will meet various inventions, founders, events, systems, and logics that is worth around 9 lectures with each conters covering over 50 ppt pages.

Still duable you think? Well only fact is that you should memorize it all. No worries, if you suceed in doing so, A is kinda gaurenteed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is okay in personal view.

Tehy are just reading through ppt and thats it.

There are three tech review section in middle of the lectures. I highly insist you to watch all three before the exam, it does help alot.
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say grading is good.

I got A- overall which was not my expectation but it worked well eventually.

The grading happens with quizzes, 2 group presentation and review section, 2500 word individual term paper and own presentation, and final exam which covers all 9 lectures at once.
reviews.comment_workload:
Yeap this is the one and only reason why you are in hell in this course.

Here are things you should complete for the course.

- 9 quizzes which each covers the contents of 50 page ppts.
- Group presentation regaridng software inventions and social delamas.
- 2500 word essay regarding the topic you choose (I would say category since the essay topic is strickly on you).
- 3 minuets presentation about the entire summary of your 2500 word term paper.
- Final examination covering all the contents of the entire lectures.

If this does not sound a lot for 3 credit course? Man I am not sure what will satify you anymore.

However, once you overcome it all the grade is worth the entire sufferages!

reviews.author: Anthonycyl
reviews.title: Good Grade Course
reviews.comment_content: Including history , present and future of IT , include a little calculations but it’s easy to handle. Very basic concept of gate . Easy to read, ard 50 pages per ppt.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Wong just read all the ppt , it’s useless to attend class. However, if u have some question during class, he will answer you, but u know... most of them are not included in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade!!!! If u were assigned to group with IT students , they can carry you in this course. Open book in the exam. You can copy the answer from your book . Super good grade!!!!!
I understood around 70% of the lecture and I got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course is a little bit high. A weekly presentation is required. And it’s during the tutorial which means u must attend all the tutorials . If u don’t attend that tutorial, u cannot get any mark from it . Although there is no homework for this course , however , the weekly presentation is going to waste plenty of time of your life.
In-class quizzes

reviews.author: JAM
reviews.comment_content: Content is not too hard for students with no engineering background, as long as you understand the lecture materials you should be just fine
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine, and it is not done in-class. The professor records the lecture and you need to watch it every week
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say the grading is quite lenient. At the end of the course I asked the TA whether grading is based on normal curve or absolute scheme and she said neither because they also consider the gap between each students.

In-video quiz : 5%
Tutorial Preparation: 15%
Tutorial Presentation: 15%
Pre Debate Write Up: 15%
Post Debate Write Up: 5%
Course Reflective Essay: 15%
Finals: 30%
Bonus (Show and Tell) : a max of 3%
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is a bit heavy. Needed to write quite many essays and prepare for the weekly presentation.

reviews.author: mwmwmw
reviews.comment_content: It is really boring, I will not recommend it if you are not interested in this course and its content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Actually pretty boring, basically you will just hear him reading out the content of the powerpoint all the time. But however, sometime he may add something that help you to understand the content easier.
reviews.comment_grading:
A-
Quit good
Quit easy to get
It is a open book exam, if you read the content once, then it is quit easy to pass.
reviews.comment_workload:
Enormous workload
One group project and one individual project
Also have weekly quize.

reviews.author: kakkazuma
reviews.comment_content:
Outline of topics
•  Dawn of a Revolution
•  The Transistor and Power of 0 and 1
•  Claude Shannon and Information Theory
•  The Silicon Revolution
•  Five Generations of Computing
•  Wired and Wireless Communications
• The Internet and World Wide Web
• Information Security  
• Computing Problems and Algorithmic
• Emerging Trends in IT
• Entrepreneurship
reviews.comment_teaching:
His lessons are boring. He just read the words on the powerpoint.
TAs are much better. They prepared well in the tutorial sections and explain them in details.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Quizzes      10%  (Best 6 out of 8 quizzes)

Topical Studies       55%  

Group presentations (20% in total)
(6%× 2    presentation content; group-basis)
(2%× 2    comments submission; group-basis)
(1%× 4    peer evaluation)

Individual Topic Study      (35% in total )

Exam (in-class)     35%   

The grading is quite good. I am a business student and I just spend 1 day reviewing the course material before final exam, I get a B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy.
Need to present in the tutorial sections for two times and two times for comment. However, they distribute the topic you need to present in Thursday, and you need to hand in the ppt and also the script 4 days after in next Tuesdays.
We need to have final and write essay for a word limit of 2000.

reviews.author: Seanhsu
reviews.comment_content:
About the history of computing and some basic concepts.

Mostly reciting things, some basic calculations involved.
Exams and quizzes test your reading comprehension skills mostly.

The lecture ppts are not ctrl-f searchable. The point is you have to actually read them and not rely on ctrl-f searching during the exam.

However, you can "acquire" the version of the lecture ppts from previous years. Those are ctrl-f searchable.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Recorded lectures
Tutorials every week
There is no need to watch the lectures, you can read it yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
35% Final
Online Quizzes(weekly) 10%
Individual Paper 35%
Group Presentations 20%
reviews.comment_workload: Group presentations every 2 week. Group comment every 2 week. You might have to spend lot of time in finding reference. Also a paper which you can choose topic by your own

reviews.author: peter_ng
reviews.comment_content:
會同你睇下D科技發展同一D基本computing知識

例如：
數字系統
Logic gate
Hamming code
等等…

都啱吾系熟IT，因為present D 資料都可以上網揾，當然你要有好隊友
reviews.comment_teaching:
個人吾太鐘意Albert…照讀PPT…
但D TA都幾有心教D tut.
reviews.comment_grading: 好Grade，我個人Essay present 失手，但都有B-
reviews.comment_workload: 要兩個星期小組present一次，Workload大吾大就見人見知…

reviews.author: eva78
reviews.title: business student覺得讀得幾辛苦
reviews.comment_content:
Outline of Topics:
• Dawn of a Revolution
• The Transistor and Power of 0 and 1
• Claude Shannon and Information Theory
• The Silicon Revolution
• Five Generations of Computing
• Wired and Wireless Communications
• The Internet and World Wide Web
• Information Security
• Computing Problems and Algorithmic • Emerging Trends in IT
• Entrepreneurship

Recommended Text:
Hey, T., Pápay G. (2015). The computing universe: a journey through a revolution. New York, USA: Cambridge University Press.
reviews.comment_teaching: Albert真係講得好差，個人覺得佢完全唔識教書，把聲好沈，講嘢好悶，9成時間照ppt讀。
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading

1. Online Quizzes Topical Studies: 10% (Best 5 out of 7 quizzes)

2. Group presentations: 20% in total
- Notes (in notes view) should be added in the PowerPoint slides
- Two or more members to make a presentation

Every member in a group must have some parts in presentations during the semester. There should be no silent member.

3. Individual Topic Study: 35% in total
- Study Guide Write-up
- Study paper with Presentation PPT - Commenting on three papers
- Presentation

4. Exam: 35%

用咗好多時間同心機，特別係individual topic study，business student真係乜都唔知，由0開始search起。
Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: 真係超級多嘢做，要做兩次group present+兩次comment，平均每兩個禮拜就有嘢做，超級煩，而且group project俾嘅時間偏少，每次都覺得好趕。個individual topic study真係超級麻煩，冇乜方向俾到你，guideline唔清晰。

reviews.author: augenstern
reviews.comment_content: hard and boring content
reviews.comment_teaching:
Boring lectures
pre-recorded videos
1. Identify the key advances in information technology and related enabler in various technology.
2. Understand how advances in information technology are applied to different fields and the revolutionary changes they brought to those fields.
3.Evaluate the key benefits and potential drawback or issues underlying these changes.
4.Recognize the future trend in information technology development and possible benefits and issues associated with these development trends.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Quizzes 6%( Best 6 out of 7 quizzes)
Group presentations: (8%× 2presentation content; group-basis)
(2%× 2comments submission; group-basis)
(1%× 4peer evaluation)
Individual Topical Study (20% in total)
Debate Statement 20%
Exam 30% (open-book)
reviews.comment_workload:
many group presentation: twice a week
quite easy if you got nice group mates
quiz every week

reviews.author: misky
reviews.comment_content:
Content is pretty simple. Some simple calculation may be required.
Not really technical. Mostly about business and history stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pretty boring.
1 regular class every week.
The topic is covered briefly and it is fine not to attend. Revising the notes will be enough to understand most of the topic.
Tutors are willing to help.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade.
Final half mc half short question.
Revise all the slides carefully and not difficult to get a good grade.
~8x%
1essay
6quiz
1debate
1final
2presentation
4 peer evaluation
no mid term
Performed badly in the assignments , still managed to get a B+.
Most of student in the class should get at least a B or above. Pretty good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
6 simple quizes.
Two presentation. 1 debate.
Refer strictly to the guideline and it is not that difficult to get a high mark.
Not much workload until the end of the semester when there are final and essay writing.

reviews.author: wg1234
reviews.comment_content: Covers the history, present and future of different technologies, eg computing machines, telephones.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are made through online video. The TAs will cover technical problems in tutorials in details. Both TAs and the professor are very willing to answer and explain to you.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading.
Online quizzes 6%
Group presentations 24%
Individual topic write-up 20%
Debate 20%
Exam 30%
reviews.comment_workload: Quite a heavy workload. Have to present every two weeks and finish a quiz every week. There is also a debate near the semester end. However, clear guidelines would be given for every task so it is still manageable.

reviews.author: DAVIDKKK
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers content of information technology and explores the many applications of it in our daily life.
Ranging from IT's history to some basic calculation of research method were included.
The PPT used in the course might be too long but the content is interesting to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor's teaching was boring that the staff in the course can be read by yourself.
Skipping class is ok but there were 5 unannounced open-book short quiz in the class.
Most of the work was in the tutorial classes that students had to present and discuss, usually graded by the TA after course and shown on canvas .
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was good.
I think the final exam is crucial to that and should better prepare for it as other work in the course can usually be done well.
reviews.comment_workload:
In-class Open-book Short Quiz (2.5% x 4)(Best 4 out of 5)
Tutorial Discussions (3% x 5)(Best 5 out of 6)
Tutorial Presentation (3% x 5)(Best 5 out of 6)
Reflective Statement 15%
Reflection on Debate  15%
Exam 35%
Bonus marks: Student show-and-tell 2%

Even though the workload of the course might seem too much, the work was generally acceptable and easy to get it done. With research to do for the essay and the exam was open with a notebook without network accessing to students.

reviews.author: deadlinefighter
reviews.comment_content: Content is mostly based on the "second machine age" where technology begins replace human intelligence, much like the first machine age where technology replaced human strength. Somewhat interesting though the content is eclipsed by the boring teaching.
reviews.comment_teaching: Style of teaching is boring and barely anyone attends lectures. Lecturer just reads off powerpoints that are posted on LMES. Don't attend lectures if you want more free time.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is very lenient. Midterm: mean + 0.9SD. Reflection essays: 39/40. Debate essay: 19/20. Final reflection essay: 19/20. Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite heavy - 1x1000 word reflection essay per week- though only two out of five are graded. Group debate and 1000 word reflection essay for debate, followed by a mid-term exam based on lecture slides. Group presentation and another 1000 word reflection essay as a final assessment.

reviews.author: ehhh
reviews.title: Pretty easy course if you're in CS/CPEG/ELEC
reviews.comment_content:
Basically covering the history on computers and communications, just some memorization work. I would say though the content might be boring to those who are really not interested in computer and semi-conductor history.

Syllabus -
(there is only 9 lectures):
1: Introduction to the course
2: Electricity
3: Digital age
4: Semiconductors
5: 5 generation of computing
6: Information theory
7: Telecom system
8: Cryptography
9: Internet and the web

Tutorial -
1: Babbage's difference machines
2: Binary number and logic
3: Turing machine
4: Huffman code
5: Repeated squaring
(there maybe more but I forgor)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eh, the professor just reads off of the PPT word by word. To be completely fair you can probably get through the content by just reading the slides yourself.

I recommend to go to the technical reviews tho, just to make sure you really understand what it is about.
reviews.comment_grading:
Most of the technical stuff would be familiar if you have taken any courses that covered logic gates, boolean algebra or some sort of mod operations like repeated squaring. So for cs or cpeg students you would probably have a better time handling the technical part of it.

For the essay, try to find a recent thing that could possibly stand out and be somewhat impactful to the society. 2500 words may sound like much, but if you followed their guidelines it is pretty easy to hit that goal.

I don't know how the distribution looks like, but I got an A+ in the end it is pretty easy to score high in the final if you are careful enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
List of the work you would do in the course:
- 1x 1.5 hour lecture per week
- 1x 1.5 tutorial per week
    - the tutorial would be a mix of technical reviews and presentations
- 1x group presentation on a specific topic, group is assigned by TAs
- 2x presentation review of other groups
- 8x online canvas quiz you would need to complete, one per week
- maybe random pop-quizzes during lecture time, this is how they
  keep track of your attendance, we only got 2 this sem
- a 2500 essay on a specific topic or event by the end of the year
    - you would need to choose the area and the thing you want to
      write about
- 1x 3 hour open book final exam with 40 MCQs, 10 T/F and some
   short question, 0 memorization required

It may seem like a lot but to be completely fair it is really spread out in the entire semester. So at most you would be spending at most 1 hour per week not counting classes on this course. Most of the tasks you would be able to complete in under 10 minutes like the presentation reviews.

reviews.author: mattam
reviews.title: Time consuming fair grade course
reviews.comment_content:
TBH quite boring
Doesnt count attendance
I skipped most lectures and just skim over the ppt right before doing the weekly online open book quizzes.
It's mostly about the history of technology with a bit of DSE ICT curriculum like gates, computer hardwares.
The exam is open book, the technical review questions are quite straight forward, just simple maths.
but the MC and TF questions are tricky and hard to find even is open book and you are not suppose to use F3 to search the pdf.
reviews.comment_teaching: the prof is nice but he just read out the ppt during the lecture with his monotone.
reviews.comment_grading:
Me total around 73% and grabbed a B.
- 10% Quizzes (best 6/8) [me almost full ]
- 40%Individual topic (essay + 3min presentation) [me ~25]
- 10%Group presentation (15-20 mins) [~8-9]
- 40%Final exam [slightly above mean]
- Peer evaluation
reviews.comment_workload:
Dogsht workload, a online quiz every week. Group and Individual Presentation, and 2500 words term paper.
If you wanna aim A grade really need to put some effort,
but if you are like me wanted to grab a B, not much effort but time consuming.
It's cool to have pro teammates to carry your group project.

reviews.author: Namida47
reviews.title: The Choice is YOURS
reviews.comment_content:
The course is rather informative, and for someone with no prior experience nor knowledge in technology, the history of computers, internet, and all the "tech stuff,"  I must truthfully say you will––as I have––learn quite a lot of things (especially the history aspect) of how many of the major technologies we use today have came to be. That being said, you may feel there is heavy content coming at you at any time, and it's important to be good at taking notes.

With this course, you will thrive if you put in the effort.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Wong is quite familiar with his slides, which are heavy with information. Our first few classes started a bit slow (which to me was...hmm, the right pace?), so we sped up later on. This meant I had to use time after class to finish my notes.
Wong's lectures don't require interaction, but he likes to make sure that we're paying attention by reminding us to switch on our cameras, at least for the first and last 5 mins of class (which I find reasonable and good as it offers everyone a sense of classroom and learning together). I also think that he has a lot of knowledge and experience on this topic.

The TAs are helpful too :)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair: even students who have no prior knowledge can get into A range, which meets the introductory level of which this course is designed.

- Quizzes (best 5/7)
- Individual topic (essay + 3min presentation)
- Group presentation (15-20 mins)
- Final exam
- Peer evaluation

The research essay is to be chosen from a range of topics and the 3 min presentation is to simply provide a summary to the essay. The grading is fair and on your research & writing skills.

One can never expect too much for group presentations. Certain topics might be easier.

Perhaps as a result of e-learning, the exam is split into 4 sections: ABCD, the question types versatile, including T/F, multiple choice, and short responses. Dr. Wong and the TAs are quite transparent about grading and will post the score break downs for each individual part.
Owing to good revision, I scored well for A and B (>1 SD above the mean) but didn't do well in one question in pt C due to time pressure (1 SD below the mean for that one). I did so-so with pt D. Overall I scored above the mean by <1 SD for the exam.

P.S. The exam is open LECTURE notes (i.e. the ppt slides by Dr. Wong)
reviews.comment_workload:
Aside from the inevitable range of assignments listed in the Grading section, the workload depends on YOU! (like me, who voluntarily put in extra effort to carry my group, even though I've got no background and they're technically CS students ...?? *tedious sigh*)

Also, studying really helps with this course; if you're willing to put in the right effort, it's quite likely that you can do well.
If you're new to information tech and tech in general, like me, study and try to engage yourself with other educational resources (e.g. videos on Computer Science, as this is somewhat a intro computer science course)

reviews.comment_content: Covers history of different types of technology.
reviews.comment_teaching: Powerpoint reading, basically everyone skipped the lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good grade, didn't get full marks for quizzes, normal performance in topical studies, 105/120 in final exam, A at last.

Online Quizzes 10%
(Best 6 out of 8 quizzes)

Topical Studies
• Group presentation (in-class) 10%
(in sub-total)
(6% presentation content; group-basis)
(2% questions/ comments submission; group-basis)
(2%. peer evaluation)

• Individual Topic Study 40%
- Proposal Write-up (2%)
- Paper (30%)
- PPT and Presentation (5%)
- Review and comment on 3 papers (3%)

Exam (in-class) 40%
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload
Got 8 quizzed throughout the semester
Basically there is one quiz after each chapter, luckily only 6 out of 8 quizzed are being counted so you can screwed up two of them.

There are really small subset of grading under topical studies, which makes the course annoying
E.g. group based comments are just 2%, peer evaluation is just 2%

reviews.author: Holand
reviews.comment_content:
There are 9 Lectures in total
1. The IT Revolution
2. Electricity and the dawn of IT revolution
3. Digital Age: The Power of 0 & 1
4. The Amazing Chips
5. Five Generations of Computing
6. Claude Shannon and Information Theory
7. Wired and Wireless Communications
8. Cryptography & The Secret World of the Web
9. The Internet and World Wide Web
reviews.comment_teaching: Albert just simply read through the PPT, so u can skip the lessons and read the PPT by yourself. But the two TAs are helpful and their tutorials are well prepared. I suggest you don't skip the tutorial as it can help you to clarify some concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Online Quiz (Best 5 out of 7 Quizzes from Lecture 3 to 9) (Me 5/6 for one quiz and full marks for the other 4)
10% Group Presentation (6% content, 2% comments from other groups, 2% peer evaluation) (Me 8.75/10)
40% Individual Term Paper (2% proposal, 30% content, 5% presentation, 3% comments on other paper) (Me 33.78/40)
40% Open Book Final Exam (Lecture 1 to 9) (Me 100.5/120, mean 81.9 SD 16.9)
My final grade is A which is over my expectation as a business student. I would say it's a good cc for non-engine students as all quizzes and exam are open books with very straightforward questions. All are just basic knowledge with very few concepts. You don't need to have a good engine mind in order to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: It takes one week to prepare for the group presentation and a month to finish the term paper. But the instructions are not clear so you may find it difficult to finish them. So I suggest you find the TA when necessary. Attendance is counted during the individual presentation.

reviews.author: wow!
reviews.comment_content:
Outline of Topics
•  Dawn of a Revolution
•  The Transistor and Power of 0 and 1
•  Claude Shannon and Information Theory
•  The Silicon Revolution
•  Five Generations of Computing
•  Wired and Wireless Communications
• The Internet and World Wide Web
• Information Security  
• Computing Problems and Algorithmic
• Emerging Trends in IT
• Entrepreneurship
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof reads the ppt out in class. His accent can be a little difficult to understand sometimes. TAs and prof do try to help if you have any questions
reviews.comment_grading: Don't trust most of the course reviews. The final is difficult and it is hard to get above mean. It is very time consuming too.
reviews.comment_workload: The heaviest workload course I've taken; 4 group presentations, 1 individual presentation, individual study paper, 9 online quizzes and 1 final. The individual study paper is a little difficult to write because the topic is too vague to write about. Group presentations can also be very tricky if you get free riders.

reviews.author: Seanpan
reviews.title: good grading
reviews.comment_content: The content is very broad, a lot of different concepts in information technology were introduced, but weren't discussed in depth.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture videos were pre-recorded, and the professor basically just reads through the notes. No need to watch any of the lecture videos, just study the notes before quizzes and the final exam. However, the professor elaborates on the topics during tutorial sessions, and attendance is required.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got around mean for the presentations. Near full mark on the quizzes(I think everyone gets around full mark).

study paper: 20.68/25
final exam: 114/120(command+f was allowed, so I got a high score even though I didn't study hard, typing fast is the key)

Got an A in the end, I would say the grading is quite generous, probably because of the heavy workload
reviews.comment_workload: Seven quizzes in total, not hard. Two group presentations, one study paper and one individual presentation. I would say the workload is pretty heavy for a 3 credit common core course. And a huge part of the total workload is jammed at the end of the semester(study paper, individual presentation, final exam).

reviews.author: mei you qian
reviews.title: If you're SBM, reconsider taking this course
reviews.comment_content:
"Basic engineering" but deadass heavy for non-seng students
(trust me, those saying it's not a bad course are probs seng)

History of electronic communications/IT & engineering technology behind them. If you don't have any physics or engineering background (like me) there are some complicated concepts and calculations which you would have no idea how to do them initially. It takes some time to fully digest these concepts - not so easy.
Everything is in slides but each week, you need to read 30+ slides full of texts with 1 or 2 pictures. Pretty deadass..
Plus, they have the messiest Canvas page I have ever seen so it is even more confusing.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The worst teaching ever (both prof and TAs)

Prof Wong is passionate but it was one of the worst teaching I had in 3 years in UST. He has a THICC local accent and it's hard to understand him most of the time. He also has that boring prof voice if you know what I mean.
He releases lectures videos every week but he literally just reads off the slides.
During the mandatory tutorial, TAs will go through these circuits and calculations but not so helpful since they absolutely suck at explaining concepts. Just go on to Youtube or Khan Academy and learn them yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
Somewhat lenient.
They never released mean so I will never know how it worked.
I've got
- full marks for weekly quizzes
- 4.65/6 for Group P1
- 4.95/6 for Group P2
- full marks for commentaries
- 21.5/25 for individual paper
- 3.5/4 for individual presentation
- 100/120 for finals
ended up with a B+.

Not worth my effort but the course was out of my element anyways so I'm not dissatisfied.
reviews.comment_workload:
You have:
- weekly lecture (30-40 pages slides) + review quizzes
- 2 group presentations + 2 commentaries for other groups
- 1 individual paper (2000 words) + presentation (6 mins)
- final exam

I seriously think this is way too much and time-consuming. Again, if you don't have engineering background, it's a very heavy workload. I personally never saw this amount of workload in any SSC courses and probs i never will.

reviews.author: DX3906
reviews.comment_content: Content of this course is quite intuitive. Especially if you have learned COMP2611 or equivalent courses, it is more like a super simplified version of COMP2611, plus some common sense knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: We have only meetings during tutorials, while all lectures are pre-recorded. I personally never watch these pre-recorded videos, a simple skim over the lecture slides will assure you good understanding of the course materials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The final exam is super easy, and the weighting of it is relatively low, which means the final grade largely depends on your group and individual projects.

Scores:
all quizes: 6/6
group p1: 4.95/6
group p2: 4.65/6
group commenting: 2/2
Individual Paper: 20.63/25
Individual review: 2.5/3
Individual presentation: 4.33/5
exam: 120/120

final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: For a non-engineering student, the workload is similar to a normal ssc course. For students of SENG, especially those who have taken COMP2611 or equivalent courses, it literally has much lower workload than other ssc courses. The exam was too simple, that I cannot believe I could encounter these questions in the exam. The weekly quizes are quick easy compare to the actual lecture materials. After all, the course doesn't expect you to understand and grasp everything taught in the lecture. You only need to have a brief impression, and know how to do a quick search among lecture slides.

reviews.author: 周防桃子
reviews.comment_content: Mainly about the history of Information technology. Topics include electricity, the internet, humming code encryption and decryption, computers.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture notes are easy to read on your own. Each Tutorial will give you a worksheet to better understand the concepts of the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got an A, very leng grade course.
The final exam is open notes but cannot ctrl+F.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload just 2 group presentations throughout and weekly quizzes that you can ctrl+F. The main workload is from typing essays on a topic but very few words are required.

reviews.author: abpuma
reviews.comment_content:
Dawn of a Revolution
•The Transistor and Power of 0 and 1
•Claude Shannon and Information Theory
• The Silicon Revolution
• Five Generations of Computing
• Wired and Wireless Communications
• The Internet and World Wide Web
• Information Security
• Computing Problems and Algorithmic
• Emerging Trends in IT
• Entrepreneurship

Mainly based on IT and computer engineering topics. Goes quite deep into technicalities of engineering.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof (Albert) doesn't have a huge role in the course. Since it's a blended-learning course, all lectures are pre-recorded by Albert and uploaded online. His accent is a bit difficult to understand.

The TAs handle most of the tutorials, and it's quite practical.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online lecture quizzes: 6% (Best 6 out of 7)

Group topical studies
   Group presentations: 16% (2x 8%)
   Comments: 4% (2x 2%)
   Peer eval: 4% (4x 1%)

Individual topical study
   Write-up: 2%
   Presentation PPT: 18%

Debate statement: 20%
Final exam: 30%
Extra 1% each for a) winning debate, b) originality in mind. presentation, c) ind. presentation is selected

My scores:
Quizzes: 6/6
Group presentations: 16.58/20
Group comments: 4/4
Ind. topic write-up: 2/2
Ind. topic ppt: 12.16/18
Debate: 18/20 (+ 1% for winning)
Final exam: 116/120

Final grade A

It's not very hard to get A-range in this course, the only problem is that there are a LOT of assessments and the course has many deadlines last 2 weeks.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is actually too much for a common core course. The weightage is divided over a large number of assessments so, there's always some deadline coming up. They put a lot of importance on the group topical studies presentations, but each one is worth only 8%. For the comments, they only give you about 36 hours to prepare and submit.

In the last 2 weeks before the end of the course, we had 2 deadlines and presentations, together worth 40% and a lot of work.

The topics will be quite a bit complex to understand if you're not an engineering student.

reviews.author: 歐叙鋒
reviews.comment_content: The class content is around the development of information tech, so if there might be chance for you to actually be interested in it. The thing they're teaching is not hard at all while you will hear a lot of the students complain yet once you start work on it you will realize is just engineering tricks (they like to make thing that are simple looks complicated). A for the content cuz is fun and actually educational.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching involves a lot of self reading and interaction. I personally enjoyed it a lot and so is those who are open to some basic engineering concepts. It was a lot harder to some of my group mates tho.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is weirdly good. I got a good score knowing I don't deserve it at all. I think this is a class where everyone gets good grades just by presenting to the class so the exams score actually matters a lot so study hard on the final cuz is just simple memorizing.
reviews.comment_workload: There will be quite a lot of presentations and after class follow-ups to do. As a group you really have to engage a lot in and out of the class. However the workload is not bad overall since even though there will be a lot to do but each task only have little work to go through. The professor will assign you into groups with different background, e.g. engineering, business, social science...; therefore you can just give the slides production to the business student while the engineering smarties can work on the theory and other tricky stuff while they don't even think is hard at all.

reviews.author: ytchiuac
reviews.title: Good grade course
reviews.comment_content: the course is about engineering technology in the past, present, and future. Do not involve a lot of calculation, mainly informative things. The final exam is open notes so don't need to memorize things.
reviews.comment_teaching: The tutorials need to attend while the lectures are online. reading materials help you to finish the presentations, would not be included in the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall I get A-.
the two presentations, debate statement, online quiz, and final exam I get around mean score.
reviews.comment_workload: A bit more than other courses, but the presentations and final exam are easy

reviews.author: soohan124
reviews.comment_content: The content itself is very boring, although the course itself has the keyword "information technology", there is more of a history aspect to the course. The difference is that while history would say event A has happened, in this course we say event A has happened, but also have to figure out the theory behind the technological revolution.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was bad, simply reading the lecture notes and nothing much beyond.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is a pleasant surprise for this course. I was very bored with the content and teaching so did not allocate enough time to study for the exam. I really did not see myself getting more than a B. The exam itself was quite hard as well, adding to my belief. However, I ended up with an A-, so there must be some generosity behind all the content load and teaching.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is good in the sense that there is not a lot of work to do in between the semester. However, if you keep delaying your exam study you will suffer come exams as the content is quite a lot and most of it is based on memorization.

reviews.author: Wong Hoi Ching
reviews.comment_content:
Maybe not very easy to understand if you do not have engineering and CS related knowledge.
But not understanding the concept is fine as the course focuses quite a large part on history.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No lectures, only lecture videos and tutorials every week.
Needed to finish a short quiz after watching the video.
The professor usually only read through the powerpoint slides in lecture videos, sometimes may explain some hard and important concepts.
There are two TAs and they are willing to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite Good!
Seems all groups got similar marks in presentations, do not know how he graded the work.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a heavy workload.
Included group presentations every two weeks, a group debate,
an individual debate essay, a 10-minute individual presentation and quizzes every week.
No midterm
You can open book in the final exam, but still need to go through the notes quite detailed during revision.
Take attendance for every tutorial.

reviews.author: man sheung lam
reviews.title: Good Grade Course
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting stuff in general. Learn about the past of technology from origin of electricity to calculators to transistors etc.

Also has some math-ish concepts like binary to decimal.

It's a blended learning approach which means you watch a powerpoint slide with the teacher's recording over it yourself every week. Mostly just reading from the slides.

Parts of the PPT are explained more in-depth in the tutorial sections.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor mostly reads from slides and TA does most of the talking in tutorial sections. Professor sometimes intervenes to tell a story about his old days.
reviews.comment_grading:
Have:
1) Individual Presentation
2) Group Presentation
3) Final Exam
4)PPT Quizzes

There are quizzes within the PPT slides but they are very easy. Can go back a few pages to look for answer

All in all, if you follow the instructions you can get B range. Don't even need to go fancy in your assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very little workload honestly. Alternates between making short slides individually in one week by every group member and then combining them into a whole presentation and presenting in the other week. Should be fine for most people.

Final exam is also open book.

reviews.author: timmmothyy
reviews.comment_content: Covers the history, present and future of different technologies, eg computing machines, telephones.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof mainly just repeat the slides. For difficult concepts, Prof will explain further in class but exam will not require very deep understanding towards the concepts. Lectures are quite boring and somehow useless unless you have questions to ask.

However, Prof is very willing to answer questions and help. TAs are very helpful to answer questions regarding the lectures and to give tips for the essays too.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade, easy to score high.
In-class open-book quiz, will choose best 4 out of 5. 10%
Weekly Tutorial Presentations, choose best 5 out of 6 presentations. 15%
Weekly Tutorial Discussion (PPT Submission), choose best 5 out of 6. 15%
Reflective Statement 15%
Reflection on Debate 10%
Final Exam 35%
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload of the course is manageable. Need to prepare a simple weekly presentation with groupmates. Not so difficult, 1 slide per group member. Presentations are during tutorials so you must attend.
Two reflective statements due at the end of semester. No other assignments.

reviews.author: 張man
reviews.comment_content:
The content is fine, if you have some COMP or CENG basic knowledge, this course would be a piece of cake for you.

-very little and simple calculating (most likely binary operation)
-more content on history and development backgrounds, but you may find it extremely boring
reviews.comment_teaching: No lectures, only weekly online video, and required to answer some simple questions, you can find the answer directly in ppt or if you pay attention to the video, it would be very easy, and should get a full mark.
reviews.comment_grading:
very good, even most our team got a lower mark than most of the other team in presents and essays

and I got a mean in exam (it is open book, the mean is around 90, but 50% is True False question (can easily get full mark), the other 50% is the same exercise from normal tutorial work.

I still got an A-
reviews.comment_workload:
A little tough, but still acceptable.

Every two weeks will have a group presentation, at the same two weeks, there will be two groups that will not be assigned any presentation topic ( they do not need to present ) but they would have to set Q&A questions for all the other group. In my tutorial section, the questions are very simple and understandable.

This is not a problem to me until there are exams(mid-terms) or heavy assignment from other course due in the same week.

reviews.author: cccccc
reviews.comment_content: About technology and innovation. Not very difficult as the PPTs are very detailed. Have to work on technical problem but tutorials will help you a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture will be conducted online. I usually just read through the notes without watching the lecture and complete the required quizzes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:
Online Quizzes 7%
Tutorial Presentations 28%
Pre-Debate Write-up 15% (1-2 page essay)
Course Reflection (PowerPoint with notes) 15%
Post-Debate Write-up 5% (1 page essay)
Exam 30% (Open book)
Bonus marks: 3%
(1% for winning the debate)
(1% for in-class presentation of Course Reflection)
(1% from instructor for originality)
reviews.comment_workload: Have to make a presentation once every 2 weeks and complete the online quiz once a week. The presentations are quite tough as you have to do a lot of research to get good grades.

reviews.author: asto
reviews.title: Excellent grading, teaching/content just so-so
reviews.comment_content:
Just “Information Technology Revolution: Past, Present and Future”, it tells you all.
Events/History related to the evolve of computer and its related technologies from 1600s to today.
Noticeable things include mechanical computers, silicon/transistors
, ENIAC, early stage of the Internet, security issues/darknet, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Most teaching will be done on online lectures. The lectures are generally fine but you know, still like just reading through the PPTs. So actually if you want to save time, you can just go through the notes themselves instead of listening to that long speech.

But beware there are QUIZZES IN THE LECTURE VIDEO(using the "Office Mix"), so if you choose to go through the notes, you may still have to click on that video, scroll it to the quizzes, and answer them.

there are tutorials called "Tech review" once per two weeks(alternate with presentation tutorials, which your group should do the presentation), basically explain something further and giving you some exercises to do in order to help you understand the lectures. You can NOT skip those tutorials (and of course the presentation one), because there will be attendence.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is excellent. Screwed up nearly everything but still got an A.
Grading Scheme:
In-video quizzes: 5%
Presentation preparation: 15%=5*3%
Presentation 15%=5*3%
Pre-debate write-up 15%
Course Reflective Statement 15%
Post-debate write-up 5%
Final 30%
Show-and-tell bonus +3%

There will be a debate near the end of the course.
Final is open book and you can take your printed lecture notes. No any other materials allowed. (But you can write on the print notes)
reviews.comment_workload:
Caution: Intensive group work. Nearly everything will be done in groups (presentation, debate, and iPeers)
But workload is generally not much (Maybe because my groupmates were not free-riding...)

reviews.author: Olivia
reviews.title: Good Grading, but Heavy Workload Course
reviews.comment_content:
Content is not hard.
Honestly learned a lot of interesting materials here.
The tutorials are compulsory, have to attend and discuss the reading materials.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is very nice and knowledgeable eventhough the lecture could be quite dry sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading: Good Grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly reflection on tutorial materials (quite a lot!)
Quiz is pure memorization => multiple choice questions, fill in the blanks, and some short questions.
Project presentation (could choose your own teammates and topics so pretty flexible).
Last time there is even a debate during tutorial hours. This is a course with one of the greatest workload I've ever taken.
It's good that the grading is pretty generous.

reviews.author: nkthetroll
reviews.comment_content: Feels like reading extracts from wiki, not hard to understand topics but won't be able to know them thoroughly
reviews.comment_teaching: Not interesting for a business student.. engineering and IT stuff do not have much to do with business esp students from accounting major
reviews.comment_grading: Got a mean score in everything, got B+ at the end, pretty good grade I would say
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload but there are numerous tasks after each lesson, like making ppt and script for presentation, but it won't take you more than 30mins every time to finish it

reviews.author: ChauChau
reviews.comment_content: 講好多有關於technology嘅發展過程同歷史，ppt好詳細，tutorial會教埋你點樣做(計數相關）題目。reading都有好多，好factual。
reviews.comment_teaching: professor就真係讀ppt，雖然周不時會加小小additional information同有小小板書，但真係好悶。當然同個course嘅內容有關，好難有咩有趣嘅方法（好似係）。TA嘅話女TA會講廣東話，用中文就可以好詳細好耐心答你，解釋technical problems就男TA會詳細清楚小小。
reviews.comment_grading: Groupmates好緊要……projects占分好大，一個presentation低分可能就會GG，有peer evaluation。Final open book, 可以用電腦 control+F。平時不定時有quiz，當attendance同計分。Tutorial要計attendance。
reviews.comment_workload: 好多reading，6個present，真係身不如死。好彩final可以open book。有兩個essay要寫。

reviews.author: Vincent Lau
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content which introduces transformation of technology from past to present.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice professor, with detailed lecture. But the tone is a little bit boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course should have a relative good grading compared to other courses. If you do well in the essay, quiz, powerpoints (everyweek) and score a normal score in final exam, you should still be able to receive an A.
This course uses absolute grading.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is relatively high as you need to prepare a powerpoint presentation with your group mates every week. There will also be unannounced quiz. There will also be an essay for you to write about.

reviews.author: Anonymous...
reviews.comment_content: Interesting, CS/CPEG students may find it easy. Lectures introduce basic knowledge in IT. 5 unannounced online quizzes will be given during lectures with 4 highest scores counted.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring. The professor just reads out the content of the powerpoint. But he is willing to answer your question if you go ask him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Nice grade
Tutorial preparation (on‐time submission, content, peer evaluation; best 5 of 6): 15%
 Tutorial presentations (evaluated on group‐basis but member must be present to receive grade; best 5 of 6): 15%
 Unannounced quizzes (best 4 of 5): 10%
 In‐class final Exam on November 29: 35%
 Course Reflective Statement (Interim and Final): 15%
 Debate Reflective Statement: 10%
 Optional show‐and‐tell bonus: 2% (1% for submission; 1% if selected by class)
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload. One group presentation per week. There is a debate, and reflective statement the debate. For quizzes and final exam, students are allowed to open everything.

reviews.author: ktashilov
reviews.comment_content: Great course to take if you are really interested in technology and innovation. The course content is based on the "Second Machine Age" book where you learn about the technological evolution and how it began replacing humans.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching method is not the best one and the TA is the one doing majority of work.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Tutorial attendance 5%
2. Participation in class discussions and quizzes 5%
3. Peer evaluation 5%
4. Project (3 parts) & Assignments 25% (5+10+5+5)
5. Mid-term Exam 30%
6. Final Exam (Non-cumulative) 30%
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was alright, it will easier for you if you are technically proficient and can talk about certain technical aspects of technology in more details. Otherwise, a lot of stuff is more or less common knowledge and can be easily deduced

reviews.author: cc01
reviews.title: Pretty good course
reviews.comment_content: The subject content is informative. Although processor tried very hard to explain everything in details, most of the time I do not understand, unless you have previous knowledge. It covers many aspect of IT.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is monotone, not too good at teaching, but is willing to answer any question you raised.
reviews.comment_grading: Easy to score high if you devote time. There will be unannounced quiz and presentation to work on in tutorial. Exam is open book.
reviews.comment_workload: Practically need to submit something every week, but you got covered if you meet good group mates.

reviews.author: Mun Kit
reviews.title: High workload but good grade
reviews.comment_content: Useful in terms of learning some basic tech knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not the best, merely reading off the powerpoint slides, but professor is helpful. Just be sure to read ahead of class and even look into the course content alone/read the textbook as otherwise going to lectures wouldn't help.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty easy if you follow instructions and complete all tasks given.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy as it involves a lot of preparation and homework each week. Groupwork is important but its not hard to manage even if your group contributes inadequately.

reviews.author: skone
reviews.title: Not bad but also not deep course
reviews.comment_content:
Around the basic knowledge of electrical engineering which is quite easy for the beginner (me).
Few calculation but very easy
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite bored teaching which made me skip almost all lessons. Professor provided video lectures in canvas.
But I think TA did very good on explaining the tutorial topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite nice.
In-class Open-book Short Quiz x5 (every quiz contained 5 T/F questions)
tutorial discussion x7
tutorial presentation(probably u will do one to two)
two reflective statements
one final exam(open notes)

Totally I got 80% and I finally obtained A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy but I think it depends.
If there are no freeriders, I think it was quite easy.
Writing reflective statement may sound difficult for some students.
Final is open-notes so actually not many pressure on studying this course

reviews.author: C.T
reviews.comment_content:
Learn about computer and innovation, quite interesting to a CS student though
u can take it if u have spare time for learning
reviews.comment_teaching:
very boring during lectures as the professor just reads out from the notes
the final exam u can bring all the notes so u dont have to remember anything at all
reviews.comment_grading: depends on the ability of your tutorial group mates for group work (group mates are assigned by TA and no swapping)
reviews.comment_workload:
seems like a 4-credit course rather than 3 credit
presentations every week, one final exam (no midterm), debate, pop-up quizzes

reviews.author: Christianedwinp
reviews.comment_content: General knowledge about information technology use from the past, present and future. Content wise is just okay for common core. Pretty interesting. Students with academic background in ECE / CPEG should found this course pretty easy because there are some parts overlapping with their foundation course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is boring. You don't have to come to lecture, but please come to tutorial since they have attendance for it.
reviews.comment_grading: Grade is lenient. Easy to get A range if you submit all the works on time.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy for a common core.
Base on Fall 2015, the course required you to do :
- preparing and present a presentation every week
- one debating session
- 1 essay summarizing the course
- 1 essay reviewing the debate
- 1 test  (openbook / not openbook -> depends on instructor)
- 5 quizzes -> only 4 quizzes will be counted to your overall score

reviews.author: hs
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
The Dawn of a Revolution
-Boolean Algebra
-Claude Shannon and Information Theory
-The Transistor and Silicon Revolution
-Five Generations of Computing
-Wired and Wireless Communications
-The Internet and World Wide Web
-Information Security
-Emerging Trends
-Entrepreneurship

Assignments:
-Weekly tutorial presentations on weekly assigned readings
-5 random MC quizzes that also count as taking attendance
-In class debate
-Essay reflection on the debate
-Essay reflection about everything you've learned (draft / final)
-Group presentation on selected topic

Most of the content is covered at a shallow level.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Weekly lectures where the professor reads the powerpoint slide verbatim. It takes a bit of willpower to stay focused.

Tutorials cover content that is barely related to the lecture topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class Open-book Short Quiz (5) 2.5% × 4 (Best 4 out of 5), total:  10%

Tutorial Presentation (5)  4% × 5 (2% Presentation, 2% Peer evaluation), total: 20%
Due Date: During each tutorial class

Reflection on Debate (1)  10%

Reflective Statement (interim assessment) 5%

Reflective Statement (final assessment) 15%

Group Project (4-5 students/group)  15% (Presentation)

Exam (Nov 25) 25%

Grading is tough but fair. The open note quizzes are pretty simple as long as you know how to ctrl+f. For everything else, just follow the provided rubrics to the letter and you'll do fine. Final exam is also open note (paper copy only), so read through the notes and know where everything is.
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload. As long as you manage your time wisely, this course should be manageable. For the group projects/debates, you will have to spend time outside of class meeting with classmates to prepare. ­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­

reviews.author: vin
reviews.comment_content: Content covered everything from the invention of transistors to cloud computing. The course content is not very interesting but the presentations by the groups during the tutorials are worth watching.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are very boring (and also scheduled at 9:00 am) but due to the surprise quizzes before lectures  one is forced to attend them. The instructor basically reads out everything from the lecture slides available on Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading: There are 5 surprise quizzes out of which 4 will count towards your grade. These are not very tough. One can score well in the weekly presentations with a decent ppt and an above average speaker. Make sure the reflective statements answer all the questions. The final is open book and not very tough.
reviews.comment_workload: One group presentation per week, one debate, one debate reflective statement, one group project, one reflective statement, 5 cumulative open book surprise quizzes and an in class open book final. Overall, quite manageable.

reviews.author: wszleung
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor's teaching was a bit boring so many ppl always skip class. But he always upload the lecture video onto lmes.
During the tutorials, the TA was able to give comments especially constructive ones for the reflective statements.
reviews.comment_grading: Exam如果記曬ppt同tutorial d野既話要拎高分就唔難. 基本上fulfill曬d requirement, 個course都好鬼好grade
reviews.comment_workload: Workload其實幾多, 每次tutorial都計attendance, 要睇readings同寫reflection 同peer evaluation. 雖然有幾次reflection都係optional, 但係要做group presentation同debate.

reviews.author: Khushi Chawla
reviews.comment_content:
•  Dawn of a Revolution
•  The Transistor and Power of 0 and 1
•  Claude Shannon and Information Theory
•  The Silicon Revolution
•  Five Generations of Computing
•  Wired and Wireless Communications
•  The Internet and World Wide Web
•  Information Security  
•  Computing Problems and Algorithmic
•  Emerging Trends in IT
•  Entrepreneurship
reviews.comment_teaching: We had recorded lectures for this course. And only once a week, there would be a class where we would be divided into groups and would be asked to do any activity. In general, I had fun in this course as I got to learn so much new content. But I never had any interaction with the professor or the TAs so can't say much about them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Quizzes 10%  (Best 5 out of 7 quizzes)
Very easy to score. Questions are usually from the ppts and questions are not that hard.

• Group presentations : 20%
(6%× 2    presentation content; group-basis)
(2%× 2    comments submission; group-basis)
(1%× 4    peer evaluation)
It does depend on the type of group you have. It does not require much effort.

• Individual Topic Study: 35%
Had to do a lot of research for this as it was my first ever topical study.

Exam: 35%
The exam was easy MCQ questions. Just make sure you have enough time to finish all the questions

My Score:
Quiz: 6/6
Group: 4.65/6 (mean
Individual:
        Proposal: 1.5/2
        Paper: 20.95/25
        Paper Review: 2/3
        Presentation: 4/5
Exam: 111/120

Final Grade A
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much workload. Just watch the recorded lectures in 2x before the quiz. And make sure your individual paper is good and that you score well in the quiz and final exam and you are good to go.

All the exams before our class had normal text on ppt so they could command+f their way in the final as the exam is open book. But for our lectures, the professor converted the pdf pages to jpeg format so no command+f. You need to know where the topics were to be able to use the ppt during exams.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: A+ does not exist
reviews.comment_content:
About the history of computing and some basic concepts.

Mostly reciting things, some basic calculations involved.
Exams and quizzes test your reading comprehension skills mostly.

The lecture ppts are not ctrl-f searchable. The point is you have to actually read them and not rely on ctrl-f searching during the exam.

However, you can "acquire" the version of the lecture ppts from previous years. Those are ctrl-f searchable.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Recorded lectures
Tutorials every week

Never watched his recorded lectures after the 1st one. He just reads from the ppt. Literally takes you 10 minutes to read the ppt yourself.

Tutorials are pretty good if you don't understand the content. Tutorials are safe to skip.
reviews.comment_grading:
35% Final
Online Quizzes(weekly) 10%
Individual Paper 35%
Group Presentations 20%

Final nearly full mark
End up with an A
Where is my A+

They didn't even release the solution of the final exam. If you go to the paper checking session, they just show you the questions you got wrong. I bet they want to reuse the paper next year.
reviews.comment_workload:
Small workload

Group presentations every 2 week. Need to make a few powerpoint slides, around 30 minutes of workload.

The only workload is the paper. They just give you a topic and you're on your own.

reviews.author: JYY
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
These are the main topics the lectures go through:
Dawn of a Revolution
The Transistor and Power of 0 and 1
Claude Shannon and Information Theory
The Silicon Revolution
Five Generations of Computing
Wired and Wireless Communications
The Internet and World Wide Web
Information Security

Also, the course presentations cover some of these information in more detail or give examples of some of the content discussed.
Although the lecture slides may seem complicated at times, the exams and quizzes are nowhere near as detailed or hard as the slides would suggest.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Only one meeting each week, which is the tutorial. The tutorials are helpful as they give you a non-graded miniquiz which is very similar to the questions you see in the final.
As for lecture, each week you watch about 30-60 min of pre-recorded videos. As english is not the prof first language, he goes a bit slow so watch them at 2x speed. Alternatively, you don't have to watch them if you're not interested as they go over a lot more details that won't be necessary on exam or quizzes, just skim lecture slides and tutorials and you'll be fine.
Prof is good, gives constructive feedback on group projects and good advice for final paper.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty good. However, final was probably too easy, especially since they allowed open-book exam with the option to use Ctrl F to find stuff in lecture slides, so mean was high, no space to make dumb mistakes.

Grading:
Online quizzes 10% (Best 5 out of 7 quizzesl)
Group Presentation: 20%
Individual Topic Study (paper): 35%
Final: 35% (4 parts, first two MC last two short answer)

My grades for reference:
Quizzes: 9.7/10
Paper: 29.44/35
Final: (Can't find the mean think they took it down, but I think overall I scored like 1-3 points over mean)

Part1: 24/30
Part2: 26/30
Part3: 27/30
Part4: 25/30

Final grade: A-
Probably should've done better, but still happy and would recommend this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload for most of the semester, only paper might take a while. There are 2 group presentations, one quiz each week (very easy, try to get full marks use Ctrl F), and a semester essay worth same as final exam.

reviews.author: HI_DLLM
reviews.comment_content:
Bored, many history of development of computing
Not interesting
there is not something that you can really learn from this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
No difference between reading notes yourself and listening to the professor
He just read something that is written in the powerpoint.
reviews.comment_grading: exam will be the deciding factor of your grade
reviews.comment_workload:
Every group have to present every tutorial
although one  member representing a group, everyone still need to do a part for the presentation

There is also a debate between two groups near the end of the semester. Although you need to pay effort to this , but it won't be count as grade. the reflective statement is the one that count the grade of it.
